msContents.summary: A Karaim translation of the Torah and the Haftarah

ab.title: Deuteronomy 14
ab.l:
You are the children of the Lord your God. You shall not draw |on| yourselves,
and you shall not make a bald place between eyes even for the dead.

Because you are a holy people to the Lord your God,
and the Lord has chosen you to be a chosen people to himself,
from among all the peoples that are on the earth.
You shall not eat any abominable thing.

These
are the animals which you shall eat: cattle, lamb of sheep, and lamb
of goats.

Fawn, deer, and buffalo,
and field hare, and antelope, and moose, and wisent.

And every animal that parts the hoof, and has a split of
hooves, that regurgitates the cud
among the animals, you shall eat it.

Only these you shall not eat
of them that only regurgitate the cud or of them that part
the split hoof: the camel, and
the hare, and the rabbit — although they
regurgitate the cud, they do not divide the hoof.
They are unclean to you.

And the
pig: although it parts the hoof,
it does not regurgitate the cud. It is unclean to you.
You shall not eat of their flesh, and you shall not touch their carcasses.
These you shall eat of all that are in the waters: all
that have fins and scales you shall eat.

And all
that does not have fins and scales: you shall not eat it. It is unclean
to you.
You shall eat every clean bird.

And this is
what you shall not eat of them: the eagle, and the vulture, and the black vulture,

And the red kite, and the falcon, and
the kite by its kind,
And every raven by its kind,

And the young of the ostrich, and the taḥmas,
and the seagull, and the hawk by its kind,

The little owl, and the
long-eared owl, and the white owl,

And the pelican,
and the carrion vulture, and the šalaḫ,

And the stork, the heron by its kind, and the
hoopoe, and the bat.

Every creeping animal
of flying creature is unclean to you. They shall not be eaten.
You shall eat every clean bird.

You shall not eat any
carrion. You shall give it to the stranger that is in your gates, and
he shall eat it, or you shall sell it to a foreigner, because you are a holy people
to the Lord your God. You shall not boil a kid in its
mother’s milk.

You shall tithe
all the crop of your seed that comes from the field
every year.

And you shall eat before the Lord
your God, in the place which he shall choose to cause his name to dwell
there, the tithe of your grain, of your must, and
of your olive oil, and the firstborns of your herds and of your flocks, so that
you may learn to fear the Lord your God
all the days.

And if the way is too much for you,
so that you are not able to carry it because
the place which the Lord your God will choose to cause his name to dwell there is too far from you
when the Lord your God will bless you,

Then
shall you give it in silver. And you shall bundle up the silver
in your hand, and you shall go to the place which the Lord your God shall choose.

And
the Levite who is in your cities: You shall not leave him, because he has no
portion or share with you.

In the course of three
years you shall bring out all the tithe of your crop the same year,
and you shall lay it up in your cities.

And the Levite shall come, because
he has no portion or share with you, and the stranger and the
orphan and the widow who are in your cities, and they shall eat
and be full, so that the Lord your God may bless you in all
the work of your hand which you do.

app.note: Heb. תַּחְמָס of unclarified meaning: ‘an unclean bird of prey’ in Klein (1987: 698), ‘an unclean bird of prey, perhaps a species of owl’ in Koehler & Baumgartner (1985: 1025). | Translated as ‘nighthawk’ in KJ2000, ESV, and by Friedman (2003). | EKar. taḥmas in C is translated as ‘nighthawk’ by Jankowski & Aqtay & Cegiołka & Çulha & Németh (2019: II 142, 249).

Heb. יַנְשׁוּף ‘long-eared owl’ (Koehler & Baumgartner 1985: 386; Klein 1987: 260). | See, however, ‘great owl’ in the KJ2000 and in Friedman (2003), and ‘short-eared owl’ in ESV. | EKar. janšuf in C is translated as ‘long-eared owl’ by Jankowski & Aqtay & Cegiołka & Çulha & Németh (2019: II 142, 249).

Heb. תִּנְשֶׁמֶתּ ‘a kind of owl, probably the white owl’ (Klein 1987: 709), ‘white owl’ (Koehler & Baumgartner 1985: 1035). | Translated as ‘white owl’ in KJ2000 and by Friedman (2003), translated as ‘barn owl’ in ESV. | EKar. tinšemet ~ tinšamet in C is translated as either as ‘white owl’ or as ‘barn owl’ by Jankowski & Aqtay & Cegiołka & Çulha & Németh (2019: II 142, 249).

Heb. קָאָת ‘pelican’ (Klein 1987: 559), ‘a species of owl (?)’ (Koehler & Baumgartner 1985: 817). | Translated as ‘pelican’ in KJ2000, and by Friedman (2003), translated as ‘tawny owl’ in ESV. | EKar. qaʾat in C is translated as ‘pelican’ by Jankowski & Aqtay & Cegiołka & Çulha & Németh (2019: II 142, 249).

Heb. שָׁלָךְ , a bird name of uncertain meaning: ‘probably the cormorant’ in Klein (1987: 662), ‘cormorant (?)’, ‘fish-owl (?)’ in Koehler & Baumgartner (1985: 978). | Translated as ‘cormorant’ in KJ2000, ESV, and by Friedman (2003). | EKar. šalaḫ in C is translated as ‘cormorant’ by Jankowski & Aqtay & Cegiołka & Çulha & Németh (2019: II 142, 249).
A literal translation of Heb. יִרְבֶּה ‘it will be numerous’. | TKow.01: much. | H: much. | C: much.
K: much; a scribal error (or a mistranslation), cf. Heb. יִרְחַק ‘it will be moved away; it will be too far’.
